oai_dc:dc.dc:title: French. Lizzie Crozier French Scrapbook, p. 45 b
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Lizzie Crozier French Scrapbook, p. 45 b. Newspaper clipping: Must Register From Aug. 10-21. [1919].
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Politics & government; Clippings; Scrapbooks; Women; Voter registration; Voting;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: C.M. McClung Historical Collection, Knox County Public Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: For information on license and use fees and acquiring high-resolution image files, contact DigitalCollections@knoxlib.org or phone 865 215-8814. Please provide a brief description of the material.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Must Register From Aug. 10-21. Estimated by Roy A. Beeler That From 5,000 to 7,500 Women Will Qualify IN CITY AND COUNTY Election Commission Selects Registrars at Meeting Next Wednesday The selection of registrars to serve in the general Knox county registration, which is to be conducted from Aug. 10 to 21, is to be taken up by the Knox county election commission at a meeting to be held next Wednesday. The commission will have to provide for the registration of the women as well as for the men, and it is estimated by Roy A. Beeler, chairman of the committee, that from 5,000 to 7,500 women may register. The same books will be used for both women and men, Mr. Beeler states. It is expected that about 15,000 men will register, Mr. Beeler asserts. About 10,000 or 12,000 of these are men residing within the twenty-six wards of Greater Knoxville. While the women will be allowed to vote only in city and presidential elections, they will be asked to register in the county precincts, as this is a general registration, and will serve for the next presidential election, which will be held in 1920. The election commission, which is composed of Mr. Beeler, as chairman, W. L. Warters, secretary, and C. C. Hood, will have to select 136 registrars, two to serve at each of the sixty-eight precincts of the city and county. Thirty-one of these precincts are in the city, there being twenty-six wards, five of which have two separate voting places. Mr. Beeler states that he is of the opinion that women can not be legally appointed as registrars in this registration, as the registration is also to qualify voters for state and county elections, in which the women can not vote. He states that if it was for a city election only, the women might be appointed as registrars.
